title: Iran Says Freed Tanker Has Unloaded Oil
text:
A tanker released from Gibraltar despite U.S. objections that it was carrying crude to Syria has unloaded its oil, a top Iranian official said, after the ship dropped anchor near a Syrian port.

Iran’s foreign ministry spokesman, Abbas Mousavi, said the Adrian Darya 1 oil tanker “had unloaded its cargo and its owner will decide about its future,” according to the state news agency IRNA late Sunday.

The Iranian oil official said the vessel was near an unspecified Mediterranean coastline, but his statement could undermine European attempts to mend fences between Tehran and Washington. The tanker was released on Aug. 18 after Iran pledged that the tanker’s cargo wouldn’t be delivered to Syria, which is under European Union sanctions due to the continuing civil war in the country.

Satellite image provided by Maxar Technologies appears to show the Adrian Darya 1 off the coast of Tartus, Syria. Photo: /Associated Press

Washington has issued a warrant seeking to confiscate the vessel and its cargo. The U.S. alleges the sale would benefit the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, which Washington has designated a terrorist organization, and accuses the ship’s managers of breaching a ban that prohibits the use of the American financial system for Iranian oil trades.

Satellite images last showed the Adrian Darya 1 was just outside of the Syrian port of Tartus on Sunday. The photos don’t show any oil transfer from the vessel to another tanker or a terminal, said Samir Madani, co-founder of shipping-tracker TankerTrackers.com.

U.S. officials have said the vessel’s anchoring in Syrian waters would undermine the credibility of European attempts to de-escalate tensions between Iran and the West.

Speaking to reporters on Sunday, Sigal Mandelker, the U.S. Treasury under secretary, said the vessels arrival in Syria showed Iran had engaged in “yet another game of deception.”

“Anyone who said the Adrian Darya 1 wasn’t headed to Syria is in denial,” U.S. national security adviser John Bolton said in a tweet late Friday. “We can talk, but Iran’s not getting any sanctions relief until it stops lying.”

In August, France proposed allowing Iran to sell at least 700,000 barrels of oil a day or granting Tehran a credit line of some $15 billion. In exchange, Iran’s foreign minister Javad Zarif offered to improve compliance with an international nuclear deal.

The Wall Street Journal previously reported the tanker’s cargo was set for Syria.

On Thursday, U.S. Defense Secretary Mark Esper told reporters in London that Washington has no current plan to seize the ship. But the U.S. has warned Egypt not to let the vessel pass through the Suez Canal, its most direct route of return to Iran, according to a U.S. official.

Egypt has repeatedly stopped Iranian tankers from crossing the canal when papers weren’t in order—a potential issue for the Adrian Darya 1. Lloyd’s Register, which normally issues safety certificates for the vessel, has stopped providing such services for the tanker, a spokeswoman for the London-based company said.

The Trump administration has also ratcheted up pressure on Iran’s oil supplies to Syria, with a string of new sanctions on Sept 5.

Write to Benoit Faucon at benoit.faucon@wsj.com
description: A tanker released from Gibraltar despite U.S. objections that it was carrying crude to Syria has unloaded its oil, a top Iranian official said, after the ship dropped anchor near a Syrian port.
